[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn how chronic CAD forms.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn how chronic CAD presents and is identified
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To learn how chronic CAD is treated.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To become familiar with risk stratification in chronic CAD.
[LIST_ITEM] Concept of myocardial oxygen supply and demand
Transient discomfort or pain sensation occurring in the precordium, provoked by stress (physical or mental) and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.
Atypical Angina: Transient discomfort or pain that is lacking one or more of the criteria of classic angina.
Angina Equivalent: Sensation of dyspnea, fatigue, or weakness as a manifestation of cardiac ischemia.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Provoked by physical or mental stress
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Exercise testing usually provokes chest pain and produces ST-segment depression
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Medical treatment with beta blockers, nitrates, or calcium channel blockers improves symptoms
Lilly LS. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007:152.
Lilly LS. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007; 152.
Lilly LS. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease. 2007:152..
Lilly LS. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease. 2007:152.
[H1] GRADING OF ANGINA PECTORIS BY THE CANADIAN CARDIOVASCULAR SOCIETY CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM.
Ordinary physical activity does not cause angina, such as walking, climbing stairs.

Angina occurs on walking or climbing stairs rapidly, walking uphill, walking or climbing stairs after a meal, or in cold, or in wind, or under emotional stress, or only during the few hours after awakening.
Angina occurs on walking more than two blocks on the level and climbing more than one flight of ordinary stairs at a normal pace and in normal conditions.
[H1] GRADING OF ANGINA PECTORIS BY THE CANADIAN CARDIOVASCULAR SOCIETY CLASSIFICATION SYSTEM.
Marked limitations of ordinary physical activity.
Angina occurs on walking one to two blocks on the level and climbing one flight of stairs in normal conditions and at a normal pace.
Inability to carry on any physical activity without discomfort—anginal symptoms may be present at rest.
[H2] DETERMINATES OF MYOCARDIAL OXYGEN SUPPLY AND DEMAND.
[LIST_ITEM] Marked reductions in DBP lead to hypoperfusion... eg. hypotension, severe aortic valve regurgitation
[LIST_ITEM] Flow to coronaries in systole reduced by:
[LIST_ITEM] local venturi effect in ascending aorta
[LIST_ITEM] Heart rate ↑ compromises diastolic filling time
[LIST_ITEM] ↑ # of contractions requires more ATP generation... this requires more oxygen
[LIST_ITEM] ↑ Force of contraction requires more ATP... increases O₂ consumption
[LIST_ITEM] Normal response to stress: vasodilation...increased blood flow/shear stress→ sympathetic activation→ EDRF - NO
[LIST_ITEM] Normal vessel: EDRF - NO outweighs α - constriction from catecholamines
[LIST_ITEM] Diseased vessel: vasoconstrictive response overcomes inadequate EDRF - NO release..."sensitized" to vasoconstrictive platelet products
[LIST_ITEM] Usually shows change during an episode
[LIST_ITEM] Typically transient ST-segment depression or T-wave flattening/inversion

|  Normal | Subendocardial ischemia |   |   | Transmural ischemia  | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | |   | ST depression (horizontal) | ST depression (downsloping) | T wave inversion | ST elevation  |
Treadmill or bicycle exercise Constant monitoring of:
[LIST_ITEM] BP (periodically) Graded increase in exercise until:
[LIST_ITEM] angina occurs with ECG changes... or
[LIST_ITEM] target heart rate is reached... or
[LIST_ITEM] SX/ECG change occurs in 1st 3-6 min. of exercise or persists > 5 min. after
[LIST_ITEM] High grade arrythmia - eg. Sustained ventricular tachycardia - occurs
[LIST_ITEM] Cardiopulmonary limitations preclude exercise beyond 2-3 min.
[LIST_ITEM] Nuclear tracer injected at peak exercise → image the heart
[LIST_ITEM] Myocardium perfused by narrowed artery “takes” up less tracer than that served by normal coronaries
[LIST_ITEM] Compare relative myocardial uptake at rest to that with exercise...
[LIST_ITEM] Exercise “cold” spots that look normal at rest... viable heart muscle served by stenotic arteries
[LIST_ITEM] Exercise cold spots that are also present at rest: dead heart muscle or very severe ↓ flow
[LIST_ITEM] Image LV wall motion at rest
[LIST_ITEM] Narrowed vessels have ↓ vasodilatory response c/w normal
[LIST_ITEM] Image for ischemia by ECG and wall motion analysis
[LIST_ITEM] Direct injection of radiopaque dye into coronary arteries
[LIST_ITEM] Carries higher risk c/w noninvasive testing
[LIST_ITEM] Most reliable method to obtain anatomical data
[LIST_ITEM] to establish Dx when uncertainty exists
[LIST_ITEM] to identify advanced CAD for potential revascularization $\overline{c}$ PCI or CABG
[LIST_ITEM] Prevent conversion of stable to unstable lesions
[LIST_ITEM] Relieve symptoms to improve quality of life
[LIST_ITEM] Counteract obesity, sedentary lifestyle, depression, and other habits (e.g. cocaine)

[LIST_ITEM] Catheter based opening of fixed artery obstruction - main use is angina not / controlled with medical Rx.
[LIST_ITEM] Relieves angina caused by stenoses of > 50-60%... esp. when more severe
[LIST_ITEM] Does not prevent acute MI in stable angina... issue is restenosis in 15-40% of pts.
Stent in its original collapsed state, is advanced into the coronary stenosis on a balloon catheter.
Lilly L, et al. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007;164.
Lilly L, et al. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007;164.
The balloon is deflated and the catheter is removed from the body, leaving the stent permanently in place.
Lilly L, et al. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007;164.
[LIST_ITEM] Surgically bypass arteries with advanced fixed obstruction
[LIST_ITEM] Involves up front risk of death, stroke, sternal infection, post-op debility
[LIST_ITEM] Prolongs life in select anatomic subsets
[LIST_ITEM] Disease can return in bypass grafts... arterial grafts preferred... left internal mammary artery to LAD
[H2] Relative Advantages of Coronary Revascularization Procedures.
[LIST_ITEM] Shorter hospital stay and easier recuperation than CABG
[LIST_ITEM] Superior to pharmacological therapy for relief of angina
[LIST_ITEM] More effective for long-term relief of angina than PCI or pharmacologic therapy
[LIST_ITEM] Most complete survival in patients with:
[LIST_ITEM] 3-vessel CAD, especially if LV contractile function is impaired
[LIST_ITEM] 2-vessel disease with tight (>75%) LAD stenosis, especially if LV contractile function is impaired
CAD, coronary artery disease; LV, left ventricle; LAD, left anterior descending coronary artery; MI, myocardial infarction.
Lilly L, et al. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease 2007;166.
[LIST_ITEM] CABG in: → [Left main stenosis signif. 3 vessel disease 2 vessel with prox. LAD] → [Especially if ↓ LV function and/or (+) stress test]
Lilly. Pathophysiology of Heart Disease, 4th Ed. Lippincott Williams, 2007. Page 165
